awd_titl_txt: Travel: 2023 International Microwave Symposium Educational Initiatives for Project Connect
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will support student participation in the 2023 IEEE International Microwave Symposium (IMS), which will be held in San Diego, CA on June 11-16, 2023. Support will be provided for an educational program called Project Connect which was initiated in 2014. The objective of the program is to increase the participation of students from underrepresented minority groups in STEM. The program provides students many exciting opportunities to learn the state-of-the-art technology advancements and interact with potential mentors in the microwave and wireless technological areas. The project aims to develop the technical interests of the student participants, motivating them to be involved in undergraduate research and interested in further studies in graduate program, which will help them develop a successful long-term professional career and contribute to the U.S. STEM workforce.  

The IEEE IMS addresses research areas in microwave technologies from MHz to THz and is the largest conference in the world in this field. The symposium has played a key role in identifying new directions for research and development. The 4-day agenda of Project Connect program includes community building and professional development, in addition to the technical events and industry exhibition at the symposium. The program’s most impactful benefit is the chance for participants to develop their professional networks and meet wireless and microwave experts from across the globe. The program will be described in IEEE Microwave Magazine, with the aim of encouraging other conferences to develop similar programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
IMS Project Connect (PC) is a program that aims to increase the STEM pipeline for underrepresented students in Electrical and Computer Engineering. Since its beginning in 2014, more than 170 undergraduate and first-year graduate students from 45 universities have participated. The program includes a 4-day agenda consisting of community building, professional development and many opportunities to enjoy the technical events and industry exhibition at the symposium. The most impactful benefit for the student participants is the chance to develop their professional networks and meet wireless and microwave experts from across the globe.

The 2023 PC program was executed to ensure the best possible experience for the students, including networking with key members of the IMS community and interacting with like-minded peers within the Project Connect cohort. The students committed to full participation in the PC activities during IMS week, and this comes with a certain amount of effort that is designed to enrich the student outcomes. The deliverable from the students was a video presentation that describes the unique interests and experiences that excited and educated the members of the student teams during the program. During the event, members of the organizing committee and graduate student volunteers at the conference guided the activities and provided mentorship. There were 20 students in the Project Connect 2023 cohort.

Demographic information for the student cohort:

Eleven were undergraduate students and 9 were graduate students. All students described their major/field as Electrical Engineering or Electrical and Computer Engineering except one who was majoring in Materials Science and Engineering. All of the graduate students and 7 of the 11 undergraduates had taken a technical elective course related to RF/microwave engineering. They were enrolled at the following Universities:

Baylor University

Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University

Florida A&M University

Texas A&M University

Texas Tech University

University of California - San Diego

University of Illinois - Chicago

University of Massachusetts - Amherst

University of Oklahoma

University of Texas - Dallas

University of Vermont

University of Virginia

University of Wisconsin - Madison

Six of the participants identified as male and 14 as female. Their average age was 22 years old with a range of 20-25 years old. Three of the 9 graduate students and 1 of the 11 undergraduate students described themselves as international students. Based on their responses to a question about their parents’ educational achievement, 4 of the 19 students would be considered first-generation college students (i.e. neither of their parents have earned a bachelor's degree). Finally, 7 students described themselves as White; 5 as Black or African-American; 3 as Asian; and 5 as Latino/a.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2023
Modified by: Thomas M Weller
